g.text: Li(1) sites of cubic LLZ with a slightly broad resonance at 62
Al MQMAS experiment was used to investigate this
broad resonance (Fig. 5). The projection of the isotropic
dimension shows an Al environment with a slight shoulder at
higher frequency region. Line shape simulations were per-
formed to extract their NMR parameters. The simulation of the
two slices taken from anisotropic dimension at these regions
give two Al environments with a
These two environments can be assigned as tetrahedral
aluminum sites of two diﬀerent phases (giving diﬀerent
chemical shi distributions), one with higher disorder (larger
bond angles) hence giving a higher quadrupolar coupling
constant. Since MQMAS NMR cannot be used as a quantitative
technique (intensity loss due to excitation diﬃculties in case of
large QCCs and dipolar couplings), an intensity comparison is
not possible for these two diﬀerent sites. The inconsistency
between the two aluminum environments observed with NMR
and the lab XRD data is further explored below.
resolution XRD study was performed at the Advanced Photon
Source (ANL) at sector 11-BM. The high resolution data shows
that the cubic phase identied by standard XRD is in fact
composed of two or more cubic phases with slightly diﬀerent
lattice constants (Fig. 6). A best-t Rietveld renement of the
data was only possible with three cubic models (with lattice
not shown) suggesting that at least one of the phases contain up
to 1.0 weight% Al which only gives a good t when substituted
with the tetrahedral Li(1) site in the model lattice. Having more
than one cubic phase LLZ containing Al in the material explains
sample. This is consistent with a mixture of closely related LLZ
phases with a slightly diﬀerent Al concentrations, indicating
) diﬀusion within the lattice has not allowed the
sample to reach complete equilibrium in the time allotted. The
3 Li(1) substitution used in the models is also
consistent with the NMR assignments and agrees with previous
The slower diﬀusion of Al cations within the
lattice has implications for the utility of the material. With
multiple sites available to the Al(
structure, consistent ionic conductivity measurements are
probably dependant upon sample homogeneity as the Al
concentration is directly tied to local Li concentration and thus
the percolation pathways. Extended annealing at 850
heating at higher temperatures should result in the cation
positions within the sample reaching an equilibrium position.
Li MAS NMR spectra for the series of samples (Fig. 3) showa
single resonance at 0.4 ppm(before annealing) which gradually
sample, two adjacent resonances due to two lithiumcontaining
phases can be assigned which is likely due to the formation of
shi is 1.95 ppm, data not shown). For the 16 hours and
(a) High resolution XRD pattern collected for the LLZ powder annealed at
C for 25 hours. (b) The inset shows the 400, 420 and 422 reﬂections. Red
arrows indicate the multi-phase character of the respective reﬂections.
